facts.text: Petition No. 126 of 1958 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 126 of 1958. Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India, for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on November 20, 1959 by DAS GUPTA J.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. November 20. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA J.-The petitioners who describe them- selves as Road-side Station Masters challenge

facts.text: Petitioners describe themselves as Road-side Station Masters.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners who describe them- selves as Road-side Station Masters challenge in this petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution the companystitutionality

facts.text: Channel of promotion for Guards to higher grade Station Masters posts notified in Central Railway Weekly Gazette No. 3 dated November 23, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: challenge in this petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution the companystitutionality of the channel of promotion for Guards to higher grade Station Masters posts as numberified in the issue of the Central Railway Weekly Gazette No. 3 dated November 23, 1951.

facts.text: Guards have promotion line: C grade Guards to B grade Guards on Rs. 100-185 then to A grade Guards on Rs. 150-225.

anchor.surface_text: Under this Notification Guards have two lines of promotion open to them. One is that by promotion, C grade Guards may become B grade Guards on Rs. 100-185 and thereafter by further promotion A grade Guaids on Rs. 150-225.

facts.text: C grade Guards eligible via Slip 45 examination for promotion to Station Masters on Rs. 150-225 scale and further promotions.

anchor.surface_text: The second line of promotion open to them is that by an examination described curiously enough as Slip 45 examination C grade Guards are eligible for promotion to posts of Station Masters on RS. 150-225 scale and thereafter to all the further promotions that are open to the Station Masters, viz., higher ,cales of Rs. 200 to Rs. 300, Rs. 260 to Rs. 350, Rs. 300 to Rs. 400 and finally Rs. 360 to Rs. 500

facts.text: B grade Guards and A grade Guards eligible on passing Slip 45 examination for Station Masters on Rs. 200-300 pay scale and higher.

anchor.surface_text: B grade Guards and A grade Guards are also on passing Slip 45 examination eligible for promotion to posts of Station Masters on Rs. 200-300 pay scale and thereafter to further promotions to the higher scales in the Station Masters line.

facts.text: Road side Station Masters on pay scale Rs. 80-170 (formerly Rs. 64-170) reach Rs. 150-225 after intermediate Rs. 100-185.

anchor.surface_text: The Road side Station Masters on pay scale of Rs. 80 to Rs. 170  the scale was formerly Rs. 64-170  can also reach by promotion the grade of Rs. 150-225 but only after going through an intermediate stage of Rs. 100-185.

facts.text: Petitioners contend that the channel enables Guards to be promoted as Station Masters, denying equal opportunity under Art. 16(1).

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners companytend that the channel of promotion in so far as it enables Guards to be promoted as Station Masters in addition to the other line of promotion open to them as Guards amounts to a denial of equal opportunity as between Road-side Station Masters and Guards in the matter of promotion and thus companytravenes the provisions of Art. 16 1  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Petitioner No. 2 after completing 32 years of service remained in grade Rs. 100-185 as Station Master, while Guards reached gazetted rank.

anchor.surface_text: As instances of how the impugned provisions in the channel of promotion are harmful to the Road-side Station Masters, the petitioners state that while the petitioner No. 2 even after companypleting 32 years of service has remained in the grade of Rs. 100-185 as Station Master, Guards of equal status and standing have reached gazetted rank within the same period of service

facts.text: Petitioner No. 3 reached Rs. 150-225 after 21 years service, Guards of standing reached Rs. 360-500, juniors superseded.

anchor.surface_text: that whereas the petitioner No, 3 has companye by promotion to the grade of Rs. 150225 after putting in 21 years of service, Guards of his standing have risen to the grade of Rs. 360-500 by virtue of the impugned channel of promotion and several of his juniors who entered the Railway service long after him as Guards have superseded him and are working in the grade of Rs. 360-500

facts.text: Petitioner No. 4 entered as Telegraph Candidate, passed exams for higher grade within 2 1/2 years after 6 1/2 years service, still in Rs. 80-170.

anchor.surface_text: that while the petitioner No. 4 having entered into service as Telegraph Candidate and having passed all the requisite examinations prescribed for the higher grade of Station Master within a period of 2 1/2 years after putting in 6 1/2 years of service is still in the grade of Rs. 80-170, Guards of his length of service and departmental qualification are entitled for promotion as an Assistant Station Master in the grade of Rs. 150-225 within about the same length of service.

facts.text: Respondents are General Manager Central Railways Bombay V.T., Chairman Railway Board New Delhi, Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents-the General Manager, Central Railways, Bombay, V.T., the Chairman Railway Board, New Delhi and the Union of India,-who companytest the application companytend that the channel of promotion providing these opportunities to Guards does number in any way companytravene the provisions of Art. 16 1  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Respondents deny that Guards become Station Masters on Rs. 150-225 at younger age than Road-side Station Masters.

anchor.surface_text: They also deny the companyrectness of the allegation that as a result of these opportunities Guards become Station Masters on Rs. 150-225 pay scale at a Younger age than Road-side Station Masters.

facts.text: Court finds it not possible to conclude relative age at which Guards or Road-side Station Masters reach Rs. 150-225.

anchor.surface_text: On the material before us it is number possible to companye to a firm companyclusion as regards the relative age at which Guards or Road-side Station Masters ordinarily reach the pay scale of Rs. 150-225.

facts.text: Appendix II of Indian Railway Establishment Code Vol. 1 classifies subordinate staff into 7 branches including Transportation (Traffic).

anchor.surface_text: It has to be numbericed first that Appendix 11 of the Indian Railway Establishment Code  Vol. 1  which prescribe rules for the recruitment and training of subordinate staff of Indian Railways classify the subordinate staff governed by the rules into 7 branches  1  Transportation  Traffic   2  Commercial  3  Transportation  Power   4  Civil Engineering  5  Store department Staff  6  Office clerks and  7  Medical.

facts.text: Transportation (Traffic) branch has groups: Station Masters, Guards, Outdoor Clerical Staff.

anchor.surface_text: Each branch again has been divided into groups. The first branch, i.e., the Transportation  Traffic  is shown as having 3 groups  i  Station Masters, Guards,  iii  Outdoor Clerical Staff.

facts.text: Rule 2 defines group as a series of classes which form a normal channel of promotion.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 2, the definition section defines a group to mean a series of classes which form a numbermal channel of promotion.

facts.text: Road-side Station Masters and Guards are recruited separately, trained separately, have distinct posts.

anchor.surface_text: We find that Road-side Station Masters and Guards are recruited separately, trained separately and the several classes of posts which are ordinarily open to them are also distinct and separate.

facts.text: Guards once become Station Masters cease to be Guards.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed however that Guards once they become Station Masters cease to be Guards and companytinue as Station Masters.

facts.text: Court concludes Road-side Station Masters and Guards form two distinct and separate classes.

anchor.surface_text: As on the admitted facts the Roadside Station Masters and Guards are, as already stated, recruited separately and trained separately and have separate avenues of promotion, the companyclusion is irresistible that they form two distinct and separate classes

facts.text: Channel of promotion for Guards peculiar to Central Railways, not in other zones.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Counsel for the petitioners stated before us that this channel of promotion for Guards is peculiar to the Central Railways, and is number number to be found in the other Zones of Indian Railways.
Article 32 of the Constitution of India
Art. 32 of the Constitution
Art. 16 1  of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Art. 16 1

concepts.unlisted_description: Equality of opportunity for all citizens in matters relating to employment or appointment to any office under the State

anchor.surface_text: The concept of equality can have no existence except with reference to matters which are common as between individuals, between whom equality is predicated. Equality of opportunity in matters of employment can be predicated only as between persons, who are either seeking the same employment, or have obtained the same employment.... There is, in our opinion, no escape from the conclusion that equality of opportunity in matters of promotion, must mean equality as between members of the same class of employees, and not equality between members of separate, independent classes.

concepts.interpretation: Road-side Station Masters and Guards form two distinct and separate classes based on separate recruitment, training, and promotion avenues

issues.text: whether Art. 16(1) of the Constitution is contravened by this channel of promotion

anchor.surface_text: affect the decision of the question whether Art. 16 1  of the Constitution is contravened by this channel of promotion. Art. 16 1  of the Constitution is in these words- There shall be equality of opportunity for all citizens in matters relating to employment or appointment to any office under the State.

issues.text: whether matters of promotion are also matters relating to employment within the meaning of Art. 16(1) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: If the equality of opportunity guaranteed to all citizens by Art. 16 1  does not extend to matters of promotion the petitioners contention that the provisions are void must fail at once. If, however, matters of promotion are also matters relating to employment within the meaning of Art. 16 1  of the Constitution,

issues.text: whether the impugned provisions amount to denial of equality of opportunity within the meaning of Art. 16(1)

anchor.surface_text: the next question we have to consider is whether the impugned provisions amount to denial of equality of opportunity within the meaning of that Article. We propose to consider the second question first, on the assumption that matters of promotion are matters relating to employment .

issues.text: whether Road-side Station Masters and Guards belong to one and the same class of employees or not

anchor.surface_text: In deciding the question whether Road-side Station Masters and Guards belong to one and the same class of employees or not, we must not be misled by the words groups or classes of posts used in the above rules The crux of the question is the nature of the differentiation between Road-side Station Masters and Guards in recruitment,

issues.text: whether the channel of promotion in so far as it enables Guards to be promoted as Station Masters amounts to a denial of equal opportunity as between Road-side Station Masters and Guards in the matter of promotion and thus contravenes Art. 16(1) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners contend that the channel of promotion in so far as it enables Guards to be promoted as Station Masters in addition to the other line of promotion open to them as Guards amounts to a denial of equal opportunity as between Road-side Station Masters and Guards in the matter of promotion and thus contravenes the provisions of Art. 16 1  of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: The channel of promotion enabling Guards to be promoted as Station Masters amounts to a denial of equal opportunity as between Road-side Station Masters and Guards in the matter of promotion and thus contravenes Art. 16(1) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: As instances of how the impugned provisions in the channel of promotion are harmful to the Road-side Station Masters, the petitioners state that while the petitioner No. 2 even after completing 32 years of service has remained in the grade of Rs. 100-185 as Station Master, Guards of equal status and standing have reached gazetted rank within the same period of service

arguments.claim: The channel of promotion providing opportunities to Guards does not in any way contravene Art. 16(1) of the Constitution.

arguments.court_reasoning: Road-side Station Masters and Guards are distinct classes; equality under Art. 16(1) applies only within same class.

arguments.claim: As a result of these opportunities, Guards do not become Station Masters on Rs. 150-225 pay scale at a younger age than Road-side Station Masters.

anchor.surface_text: They also deny the correctness of the allegation that as a result of these opportunities Guards become Station Masters on Rs. 150-225 pay scale at a Younger age than Road-side Station Masters.

arguments.claim: Equality of opportunity under Art. 16(1) in matters of promotion means equality as between members of the same class of employees, and not equality between members of separate, independent classes.

anchor.surface_text: The concept of equality can have no existence except with reference to matters which are common as between individuals, between whom equality is predicated. Equality of opportunity in matters of employment can be predicated only as between persons, who are either seeking the same employment, or have obtained the same employment.... There is, in our opinion, no escape from the conclusion that equality of opportunity in matters of promotion, must mean equality as between members of the same class of employees, and not equality between members of separate, independent classes.

arguments.claim: Road-side Station Masters and Guards are recruited separately, trained separately, have distinct posts and separate avenues of promotion, forming two distinct and separate classes.

anchor.surface_text: We find that Road-side Station Masters and Guards are recruited separately, trained separately and the several classes of posts which are ordinarily open to them are also distinct and separate.... As on the admitted facts the Roadside Station Masters and Guards are, as already stated, recruited separately and trained separately and have separate avenues of promotion, the conclusion is irresistible that they form two distinct and separate classes

arguments.claim: Even assuming the petitioners' allegations about relative progress and age are true, it does not affect whether Art. 16(1) is contravened by the channel of promotion.

anchor.surface_text: On the material before us it is not possible to come to a firm conclusion as regards the relative age at which Guards or Road-side Station Masters ordinarily reach the pay scale of Rs. 150-225. Assuming, however, the position to be as stated in the petition, that may only evoke some sympathy for the Road-side Station Masters, but does not in any way affect the decision of the question whether Art. 16 1  of the Constitution is contravened by this channel of promotion.

arguments.claim: It is unnecessary to decide whether matters of promotion are included in 'matters relating to employment' under Art. 16(1), as there is no violation in any case.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this conclusion it is unnecessary for the purpose of the present case to decide the other question whether matters of promotion are included in the words matters relating to employment in Article 16 1  of the Constitution. For even assuming that they are so included, the present application must be rejected on the simple ground that the petitioners belong to a wholly distinct and separate class from Guards and so there can be no question of equality of opportunity in matters of promotion as between the petitioners and Guards.

holdings.text: equality of opportunity in matters of promotion, must mean equality as between members of the same class of employees, and not equality between members of separate, independent classes.

anchor.surface_text: There is, in our opinion, no escape from the conclusion that equality of opportunity in matters of promotion, must mean equality as between members of the same class of employees, and not equality between members of separate, independent classes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Equality predicated only on common matters between individuals seeking or having same employment; illustrated by distinct requirements/promotions for professors vs school teachers.

holdings.text: Road-side Station Masters and Guards are recruited separately, trained separately and the several classes of posts which are ordinarily open to them are also distinct and separate.

anchor.surface_text: We find that Road-side Station Masters and Guards are recruited separately, trained separately and the several classes of posts which are ordinarily open to them are also distinct and separate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on Indian Railway Establishment Code Appendix II classifying into branches/groups with separate recruitment, training, and promotion channels for Station Masters group and Guards group.

holdings.text: As on the admitted facts the Roadside Station Masters and Guards are, as already stated, recruited separately and trained separately and have separate avenues of promotion, the conclusion is irresistible that they form two distinct and separate classes as between whom there is no scope for predicating equality or inequality of opportunity in matters of promotion.

anchor.surface_text: As on the admitted facts the Roadside Station Masters and Guards are, as already stated, recruited separately and trained separately and have separate avenues of promotion, the conclusion is irresistible that they form two distinct and separate classes
